INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
 
Borrower  Papua New Guinea (PNG) 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention

Assessment 
   
Investment Program  The  Investment  Program  focuses  on  the  Highlands  core  road 
Description  network (HCRN) of 2,500 kilometers (km) of major national and 
some provincial roads, which carry the bulk of the traffic in the 
region. The Investment Program will include (i) projects to improve 
about 1,400 km of the HCRN, to be funded through four or more 
tranches  under  this  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF); 
(ii)  design  and  supervision  of  road  improvement  works, 
preparation  and  administration  of  long-term  road  maintenance 
contracts  for  the  entire  2,500  km  of  the  HCRN,  and  capacity 
development  of  road  agencies;  and  (iii)  monitoring  the 
socioeconomic benefits of the improved and maintained roads in 
the Highlands region. Support will also be provided for policies 
such as road user charges (to increase the resources available for 
road maintenance). In addition, technical assistance (TA) will be 
provided to support the Department of Transport to prepare a new 
National Transport Development Plan (NTDP) for 2011–2020. 
   
Multitranche Financing  ADB’s multitranche financing facility is the most suitable modality 
Facility  for financing the Investment Program because: (i) it supports the 
Government’s long-term vision for the sector, as outlined in the 
current NTDP, 2006–2010; (ii) it enables ADB to sustain the long-
term  partnership  that  is  needed  to  institutionalize  road 
maintenance; (iii) it allows ADB to strengthen and improve the 
NTDP and actively to pursue policy dialogue throughout the life of 
the Investment Program; (iv) it responds to the long-term capacity 
development needs of the road agencies; (v) it provides flexibility 
to  the  Government  in  terms  of  timing  and  the  size  of  the 
investments for each tranche; (vi) it provides an opportunity to 
apply lessons from early tranches to guide subsequent tranches 
and  to  include  incentives  for  reforms  and  implementation 
efficiency;  and  (vii)  it  provides  comfort  to  private  companies 
interested in pursuing long-term opportunities in the road sector. 
   
Rationale  The Highlands region is a major contributor to the PNG economy 
through its agricultural and mineral exports. It is also home to 40% 
of the country’s population, who rely almost exclusively on the

ii 
road  network  for  movement  of  people  and  goods.  The  road 
network is vulnerable because of the mountainous terrain, the 
fragile geological conditions, and the climate. The Government 
and  its  development  partners  have  invested  significantly  in 
improving the road network, but a lack of regular maintenance has 
left the network in a poor condition. There is a need to (i) initiate a 
program of regular maintenance on all HCRN roads that are in 
good condition, and (ii) improve those HCRN roads that are in a 
poor condition and ensure that routine maintenance begins on 
these roads as soon as the improvement works are done.  
 
The current NTDP provides a framework of policies and strategies 
for  a  sustainable  road  system  in  PNG.  It  has  led  to  the 
establishment  of  the  National  Roads  Authority  (NRA)  with 
responsibility for maintaining the road network and a road fund 
financed through road user charges to finance road maintenance. 
The NRA and the road fund are managed by an independent 
board, with representatives from road users, the private sector, 
and the Government. There is a need to translate these initiatives 
into a workable system by (i) strengthening the NRA’s capacity to 
plan  and  manage  road  maintenance  works,  (ii)  seeking  more 
financing for the road fund by rationalizing road user charges, and 
(iii)  awarding  long-term  performance-based  road  maintenance 
contracts. With a functioning board and staff recruitment for the 
NRA underway, the Government is keen to support the MFF. It 
will help to enable implementation of the NTDP and to ensure a 
sustainable road system in the Highlands region. This initiative 
could serve as model for other regions of PNG.   
   
Impact and Outcome  The Investment Program will make ports, markets, and livelihood 
opportunities more accessible, and will lead to savings in travel 
time and transport costs. It will enable use of the natural, mineral 
and human resources of the Highlands region to be maximized, 
contributing  to  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development 
Strategy  (MTDS),  2005–2010  objectives  of  (i)  export-driven 
economic growth; (ii) rural development and poverty reduction; 
(iii)  good  governance;  and  (iv)  promotion  of  sustainable 
agriculture, forestry, fisheries, and tourism.  
   
Investment Plan  The total Investment Program cost is estimated at $750 million 
equivalent. The total cost of Project 1, including taxes, duties, 
physical, and price contingencies, interest, and other charges is 
estimated at $140 million equivalent.

To help finance Project 1, the first tranche will comprise of two 
loans  totaling  $100.0  million  equivalent  from  Special  Funds 
resources (a “hard-term” ADF loan of $28.8 million equivalent and

Implementation  The  DOW  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  Investment 
Arrangements  Program. The DOW will also be the Implementing Agency for the 
road  improvement  works.  The  NRA  will  be  the  Implementing 
Agency  for  road  maintenance.  This  will  include  all  road 
maintenance works contracted directly by the NRA or transferred 
from  the  DOW.  The  Highlands  Road  Management  Group 
(HRMG), which is the DOW project implementation unit for the 
ongoing ADB loans, will be responsible for implementing road 
improvement  works.  A  project  implementation  unit  will  be 
established in the NRA. 
   
Procurement  All  ADB-financed  procurement  for  goods  and  services  will  be 
carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time). International competitive 
bidding procedures will be followed for all contracts over $3 million 
for civil works and $0.5 million for goods. National competitive 
bidding  will  be  used  for  contracts  under  these  thresholds. 
Shopping can be used for goods with contract values lower than 
$100,000,  as  appropriate.  Contracts  have  been  packaged  to 
attract international contractors as well as to promote national 
contractors.

Consulting Services  Consulting services will be required for implementation support 
and capacity development. Key tasks include (i) design of road 
improvement  works;  (ii)  preparation  of  bid  documents, 
procurement support, and supervision of road improvement and 
long-term maintenance contracts; (iii) performance management; 
(iv) preparation of subsequent projects; (v) capacity development; 
and  (vi)  socioeconomic  monitoring.  The  capacity  development 
activities will focus on, among others, strengthening of the DOW, 
NRA  and  National  Road  Safety  Council  (NRSC)  in  financial 
management,  road  maintenance  contracting,  road  safety,  and 
rationalizing road user charges.  
 
Project  1  will  require  a  total  of  1,266  person-months  (362 
international and 904 national) of services from consulting firms. 
Additional  consulting  services,  if  necessary,  will  be  procured 
under  subsequent  projects.  The  consulting  services  will  be 
financed from the ADB loans. The DOW will select and engage 
the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method. 
   
Investment Program  While the entire 1.9 million population of the Highlands region will 
Benefits and  benefit from the Investment Program, the immediate beneficiaries 
Beneficiaries  of  Project  1  will  be  the  400,000  people  living  near  the  roads 
included in Project 1. Anticipated economic benefits will include: 
(i) increased diversity of cash crops, higher production, and more 
direct sales as a result of better access to regional markets and 
towns; (ii) rehabilitation of abandoned coffee gardens and/or the 
establishment of new gardens; (iii) more raising of livestock for 
sale; (iv) more sales by market vendors because of the increase 
in customers; (v) better businesses for trade store owners; and 
(vi)  more  opportunities  for  creation  and/or  expansion  of 
microenterprises  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises 
(SMEs). The greater availability, frequency, and reliability and the 
lower costs of transport services will benefit public motor vehicle 
drivers  and  truckers  as  well  as  people  who  rely  on  them. 
Anticipated social benefits will include (i) greater accessibility to 
schools, leading to higher enrollments, fewer drop-outs and better 
academic performance; (ii) better access to health care, leading to 
improved  health  outcomes;  (iii)  more  access  to  government 
services,  including  new  services  such  electricity;  (iv)  more 
opportunities  to  diversify  and  expand  agricultural  production, 
market  cash  crops,  livestock  and  other  products  and,  as  a 
consequence, higher household income; (v) a reduction in dust 
and  better  health  and  living  conditions  in  roadside  villages; 
and (vi) greater opportunities to travel more easily and cheaply for 
health, education, social and family reasons, as well as to seek 
work or conduct business. These benefits will reach people living 
in upstream areas and off-road communities, as well as those 
immediately adjacent to the rehabilitated roads.

vi 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The major risks include the following: 
 
NRA’s  Effectiveness.  Although  the  NRA  board  started 
functioning in 2004, the NRA has remained inadequately staffed. 
A  chief  executive  officer  was  appointed  in  2007.  The  3-year 
duration  of  the  board  expired  in  2007  and  a  new  board  was 
approved on 14 May 2008. The NRA is now actively recruiting key 
staff. Initial assistance for operational and financial management 
system will be provided through ongoing TA, and complemented 
by  extensive  capacity  development  under  the  Investment 
Program. Capacity development of the NRA and improving its 
effectiveness is critical to the success of the Investment Program.  
 
Road Maintenance Funding. The NRA manages a road fund 
financed through a fuel levy based on very low rates. The NRA is 
also authorized and plans to collect road damage charges on 
heavy vehicles. Supplemented by Government financing, these 
resources are barely adequate to maintain the HCRN. Additional 
resources  are  needed  to  expand  NRA’s  maintenance 
responsibility to maintain the entire national road network. The 
Investment Program includes assistance to the NRA to prepare 
fresh proposals for the Government to increase road maintenance 
funding. Political support for such proposals will be crucial.   
 
Shortage of Civil Work Contractors. Implementation of ongoing 
road-related  works  has  been  adversely  affected  by  a  lack  of 
capable  international  and  national  contractors.  The  problem  is 
compounded in the Highlands region by security conditions. The 
Government is aware of the issues and is taking measures to 
(i)  provide  safety  to  international  contractors  through  the 
provincial  governments,  and  (ii)  improve  licensing  and 
classification of national contractors, and provide opportunities to 
SME  construction  industry.  It  is  expected  that  the  long-term 
maintenance contracts will attract international contractors and 
facilitate joint ventures with national firms.  
 
Land Acquisition and Resettlement. Because of the prevalence 
of customary landholding in PNG, land acquisition is intricate and 
the  process  is  long.  The  DOW  normally  seeks  approval  of 
communities to carry out improvement work on roads through a 
memorandum of agreement, without formal acquisition. This has 
led to regular interruptions of work on the ongoing road projects in 
the  Highlands  region.  However,  the  DOW  has  now  started  to 
acquire rights of way for major roads in the Highlands region. The 
Investment Program will help the DOW to carry out field surveys 
and  prepare  land  acquisition  documents  for  all  Investment 
Program roads to enable it to make payments and acquire rights 
of way.  
 
Security. Security in the Highlands region remains an issue with

addresses this issue.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to Papua New Guinea (PNG) for the Highlands Region 
Road Improvement Investment Program. The report also describes technical assistance (TA) for 
preparing  the  10-year  national  transport  development  plan,  2011–2020,  and,  if  the  Board 
approves the proposed MFF, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will 
approve  the  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  Investment  Program  is  in 
Appendix 1.   
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES  
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  PNG sits between Asia and the Pacific. It comprises the eastern half of the island of New 
Guinea, together with the island provinces of East and West New Britain, New Ireland, North 
Solomons (Bougainville) and Manus, and some 600 associated islands. The total land area is 
about  460,000  square  kilometers  (km2)  of  which  only  some  7,300  km2  is  inhibited  by  a 
population of over 6 million. Roads provide the main means of access for most of the mainland 
population and road transport is by far the dominant mode of travel. For the island provinces 
and some of the mainland provinces without land connections, domestic aviation and coastal 
shipping play important roles.  
 
3.  Economic growth in PNG is surging as high oil and mineral prices boost Government 
revenues. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth reached 6.2% in 2007, about double the 
average rate of recent years, and is projected to rise to 6.6% in 2008, before easing to 4.6% in 
2009. Business confidence has generally improved, assisted by some structural reform and a 
relatively stable political environment. Revenue windfalls from the oil and minerals boom have 
greatly improved the overall fiscal and debt position. Mining and petroleum revenue grew by 
59% in real terms in 2005, by 72% in 2006, and by 15% in 2007. The Government’s total debt 
(domestic and external) has more than halved since 2002 and reached 35% of GDP by the end 
of 2007. It is projected to decline to about 27% of GDP by 2010. The ratio of external debt to 
GDP  of  18%  in  2007  is  well  below  the  30%  maximum  threshold  set  by  the  International 
Monetary Fund. By the end of 2007, savings from windfall revenue in trust accounts had 
accumulated to K2.3 billion (about 12% of GDP or $800 million), providing an opportunity to 
fund maintenance and investment of infrastructure, among other public services.  
 
4.  The Highlands region comprises five provinces (Chimbu, Enga, Southern, Eastern, and 
Western  Highlands)  and  is  the  country’s  primary  source  of  national  income  and  export 
earnings.1 The major gold reserves are in Enga and almost all oil and gas production is in 
Southern Highlands. The region is also known for its agricultural exports, including coffee, tea, 
and vegetables. About 40% of the PNG population lives in the Highlands region. The terrain is 
rugged, with high mountain ranges, steep valleys and fast-flowing rivers. The road network 
provides a lifeline for exports as well as for supplies to the resource enclaves and the general 
population. The Highlands Highway and roads leading from it form the largest contiguous 
network, linking the Highlands provinces with the main port at Lae. However, high rainfall, 
seismic activities, fragile geological conditions and a highly dispersed population make the road 
network difficult to develop and sustain.   
 
                                                 
1  Minerals and petroleum alone accounts for nearly 80% of exports (World Bank. 2002. Country Assistance Strategy 
for Papua New Guinea for FY2008–FY2011. Sydney. [November]).

2 
5.  The road network is classified into national, provincial, and district roads. National roads 
link provincial capitals and the main population centers. The national road network is 7,600 
kilometers (km), of which 2,600 km are sealed and the rest are gravel roads. Provincial and 
district roads provide the secondary and tertiary links to the national road network. Their total 
length is about 10,000 km, of which only about 1,000 km are sealed and the remainder are 
gravel or unpaved. The traffic volumes on the national highway network are low, except for the 
urban centers of Port Moresby and Lae. Traffic on 74% of the national road network is fewer 
than 500 vehicles per day. Only about 40% of the national road network is considered to be in a 
maintainable condition and the remainder requires some significant rehabilitation, restoration, or 
reconstruction to make the roads usable. Based on the Department of Works (DOW) road asset 
management system (RAMS), the condition of national roads in the Highlands region is poorer 
than the overall national road network. The annual investment in the road sector has averaged 
K500 million over the last 3 years, with a very small proportion spent on maintenance.2   
 
6.  The  Department  of  Transport  (DOT)  is  responsible  for  national  transport  policy 
formulation, planning, safety, and regulation. The DOW is responsible for carrying out works on 
the  national  road  network.  The  provincial  and  local  governments  are  responsible  for  the 
maintenance and development of all provincial and district roads. The provincial offices of the 
DOW  provide  technical  advice  and  support  to  the  provincial  governments.  As  part  of  the 
Government’s efforts to create autonomous organizations to manage transport, the National 
Roads Authority (NRA) was established in 2003 to take over the responsibility of maintaining the 
national road network, starting with the roads in the Highlands region. In addition, a road fund 
financed from road user charges was created to provide a sustainable source of finance for road 
maintenance. An independent board oversees the functions of the NRA and the use of the road 
fund.  The  11-member  board  comprises  representative  of  the  private  sector  (chamber  of 
commerce), road users (commercial transporters), institutions (engineering and accounting) and 
the Government (departments of transport, works, planning and treasury). To promote road 
safety, in 1997 the Government established a National Road Safety Council (NRSC) to advise 
the Government on road safety matters, recommend road safety actions to the appropriate 
authorities,  conduct  educational  campaigns,  and  promote  road  safety  research.  The  14 
members of NRSC include the representatives of the departments of transport and works, 
finance and planning, health, education, provincial and local government, lands and physical 
planning,  national  capital  district  commission,  motor  vehicles  insurance  trust,  chamber  of 
commerce, and universities. It is funded from a 5% levy on motor vehicle insurance premiums. 
An analysis of the road sector is in Appendix 2.

8.  PNG’s development partners have given considerable support to road maintenance.5 
The Government has reflected the need for sustainable road maintenance in the National

responsibility for maintenance of national roads to the NRA, starting with the roads in the 
Highlands region, (ii) using RAMS to analyze maintenance needs for individual road sections

implementation of the NTDP will enable the large routine and periodic maintenance program to 
be implemented. The initial focus will be on maintaining national roads, followed by provincial 
and district roads.

most Pacific countries. While institutional reforms have been undertaken in PNG, policies and 
strategies  outlined,  and  development  plans  prepared,  implementation  has  often  suffered

consultation with the Government and private sector counterparts and to undertake capacity

have been improved to acceptable levels, work on other national and provincial roads will be

12.  Road Safety. The road accident and injury rates for PNG are estimated to be among the 
highest in the Pacific region. Although recent data are lacking,10 the road fatality rate in 2002

higher  than  in  the  best  performing  countries.  The  economic  cost  of  road  accidents  was

drunk driving, inadequate road safety awareness by drivers and pedestrians, lack of safety 
considerations in road design, hazardous roads, and inadequate enforcement of traffic rules.

NRSC  is  seeking  to  expand  into  vehicle  safety  enforcement  and  is  in  the  process  of  re-

safety audit functions need to be incorporated into design, hazard identification, and safety

2.  Government’s Strategy and Ongoing Efforts 
 
15.  The  NTDP  provides  a  policy  framework  and  investment  plan  for  road  sector 
development  to  achieve  the  objectives  of  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development 
Strategy (MTDS), 2005–2010. It prioritizes maintenance and improvement of the existing road 
infrastructure. The investment priorities in the road sector are assigned to 16 national road 
corridors, several of which are in the Highlands region. The NTDP stresses the importance of 
institutional reforms, including enabling the NRA to undertake road maintenance and the NRSC 
to promote road safety.  
 
16.  The NTDP’s overall aim is to provide safe and dependable transport services to all 
sections of the community in a cost-efficient and effective manner. Specifically, NTDP plans to 
offer (i) better transport access to education, health, and other social services, especially for 
rural communities; (ii) more access to production sites and markets at lower transport costs;  
(iii) better opportunities for raising incomes in remote and impoverished coastal rural areas; and 
(iv) lower transport costs and safer movement of passengers and goods. This will be achieved 
by  (i)  maintaining  and  improving  the  existing  infrastructure  and  services;  (ii)  upgrading, 
rehabilitating and improving infrastructure that is economically feasible; and (iii) giving high 
priority to safety and security. Other policy initiatives include (i) new approaches to funding and 
finance,  in  particular  the  introduction  of  road  user  cost  recovery  to  generate  the  required 
revenue for maintenance activities; (ii) promoting stronger partnerships with the private sector; 
(iii) seeking a closer working relationship between national and provincial governments; and  
(iv) adopting more integrated and strategic approaches to transport planning, policy formulation 
and decision making. However, implementation of the NTDP has been slow. 
 
17.  The NRA was established in 2003 and a governing board was appointed in 2004. 
However, its executive was not permanently staffed until the appointment of a chief executive 
officer in 2007. The 3-year duration of the board expired in 2007 and a new board was approved

TA (footnote 5). The road fund, financed by road user charges, has been operational since 
2006. Efforts are underway to expand other sources of finance for maintenance since, although 
the NRSC has major plans to expand its operations, it faces a shortage of resources.

5.  Lessons  
 
23.  One of the key lessons from past initiatives in the road sector is the need to ensure 
sustainable  maintenance  before  undertaking  road  development  and  improvement  projects. 
Examples of roads showing signs of deterioration within 2 years of construction because of a 
lack  of  routine  maintenance  are  quite  common  in  the  Highlands  region.  Sustainable 
maintenance  includes  not  only  institutional  arrangements  but,  more  importantly,  a  regular 
source  of  financing  and  delivery  mechanisms.  AusAID’s  Key  Roads  for  Growth  Project14 
demonstrated the benefits of long-term maintenance contracts that not only ensured good road 
conditions but also provided livelihood opportunities to the roadside communities.   
 
24.  A major barrier to development in the Pacific is the lack of capacity in the agencies 
responsible for service delivery. PNG is no exception. Road agencies such as the DOW, NRA, 
and the NRSC need to be strengthened and this should complement the ongoing initiatives by 
other development partners, particularly AusAID’s TSSP (para. 20). 
 
25.  Several lessons can be learned from the ongoing ADB projects in the Highlands region:  
(i) project consultants should have direct responsibility for design and supervision rather than 
playing an advisory role, (ii) contract packages need to be designed so as to attract good 
contractors,15 and (iii) the DOW initiative to acquire rights of way of the national roads should be 
supported. Governance-related lessons are in para. 60. 
 
6.  Rationale for ADB Support 
 
26.  The NTDP provides a framework of policies and strategies to achieve a sustainable road 
system in PNG. It led to the establishment of the NRA with responsibility for maintaining the 
road  network  and  to  a  road  fund  financed  through  road  user  charges  to  finance  road 
maintenance.  The  NRA  and  road  fund  are  managed  by  an  independent  board  with 
representatives from road users, the private sector, and the Government. There is a need to 
translate these initiatives into a workable system by (i) strengthening the NRA’s capacity to plan 
and manage road maintenance works, (ii) seeking increased financing for the road fund by 
rationalizing  road  user  charges,  and  (iii)  awarding  long-term  performance-based  road 
maintenance contracts.  
 
27.  The Highlands region is a major contributor to PNG’s economy through its agricultural 
and mineral exports. It is also home to 40% of the country’s population, who rely almost 
exclusively on the road network for movement of people and goods. The road network is 
vulnerable  because  of  the  mountainous  terrain,  the  fragile  geological  conditions,  and  the 
climate. The Government and its development partners have invested significantly in improving 
the road network, but a lack of regular maintenance has left it in a poor condition. Past capacity 
development  initiatives,  such  as  RAMS,  have  been  useful  in  prioritizing  maintenance 
investments, but its use has been limited. There is a need to (i) initiate a program of regular 
maintenance on all HCRN roads that are in good condition, and (ii) improve those HCRN roads 
that are in a poor condition and ensure that routine maintenance begins on these roads as soon 
as the improvement works are done.

C.  Special Features 
  1.  Operationalization of the NRA 
 
34.  Inadequate funding of routine maintenance is a major cause of unsustainable road 
networks. Failure to perform regular routine maintenance results in a rapid deterioration of roads 
to the extent that major rehabilitation or reconstruction is required. This cycle of inadequate 
maintenance leading to accelerated deterioration and rehabilitation is self-perpetuating because 
the urgency of repairs to roads that are failing draws funds away from the routine maintenance 
that could have prevented the problem. 
 
35.  The design of the Investment Program is therefore predicated on providing sustainable 
routine maintenance so that the investment in rehabilitation and upgrading of the project roads 
is not dissipated through neglect. The roads will be managed by an organization whose primary 
focus is road maintenance. Establishment of the NRA is a key institutional policy set out in the 
NDTP. Details of the NRA can be found in Appendix 5. The Investment Program will include 
assistance to the newly formed NRA to (i) enable it to take responsibility for managing HCRN, 
and  (ii)  seek  policy  reforms  to  generate  adequate  resources  for  the  road  fund  to  finance 
maintenance. 
  
2.  Long-Term Maintenance Contracts 
 
36.  Long-term  maintenance  contracts  will  be  an  integral  component  of  the  Investment 
Program. For the 1,400 km of the HCRN to be improved, the civil work contractors will be 
responsible for improving the road and maintaining it to a specified standard for the remainder 
of a 10-year contract period. The DOW will transfer responsibility for these roads to the NRA 
once improvement works are completed. The maintenance contracts will be “performance-
based” with fixed monthly payments that will be subject to performance standards being met, 
and will include penalties for underperformance. The roadside communities will benefit from the 
livelihood  opportunities  offered  under  these  contracts,  particularly  in  carrying  out  routine 
maintenance tasks such as vegetation control and culvert cleaning (para. 23).   
 
37.  About 1,100 km of other major roads in the HCRN (Appendix 6) that are currently 
maintainable  will  also  be  included  in  the  Investment  Program,  to  ensure  that  it  does  not 
concentrate only on rehabilitated roads. These roads will be transferred to the NRA and placed 
under  10-year  maintenance  contracts  that  may  initially  be  “output-based”  contracts,  with 
provision to convert them to “performance-based” contracts after 2 years. A proposed work plan 
for maintenance of roads by the NRA is in Appendix 6. These contracts may also include a 
provision to check overloaded vehicles.

3.  Road User Charges 
 
38.  If the HCRN is to be sustainable, adequate resources will be needed to fund road 
maintenance. Road user charges are proposed in the NTDP and are provided for in the National 
Roads Authority Act, which was developed through ADB-financed TA.18 The National Roads 
Authority Act allows road maintenance funds to be generated through a fuel levy on the sale of 
diesel19 and road damage charges on heavy vehicles. About K16 million a year has collected 
through the fuel levy since 2005. This amount is deposited in the road fund, which has now 
reached  about  K49  million.  The  NRA  is  currently  making  arrangements  for  road  damage 
charges  to  be  collected  from  heavily-loaded  vehicles,  which  is  expected  to  yield  another  
K10  million  a  year.  The  Government  supplements  NRA  resources  by  K20  million  a  year 
(Appendix 5). Consultants will help the NRA to rationalize and manage road user charges and 
to raise awareness of the need for adequate maintenance funding.20 
 
  4.  Private Sector Participation 
 
39.  The road network in the Highlands region is heavily used by companies involved in gold,

  7.  Road Transport Services 
 
42.  Vehicle ownership in the Highlands region is very low. Travel is almost entirely by 
commercial passenger and goods transport services. These services are regulated and fares 
are  set  by  the  Independent  Consumer  and  Competition  Commission.  Services  are  almost 
entirely “on demand” with no formal timetables. This is ideal for heavily used routes, but can 
lead to chronic underprovision on low-density routes. The Investment Program will include a 
review of the adequacy of existing passenger and freight services in the region and will make 
recommendations for administrative or regulatory reforms as needed.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits  
69.  Although the entire 1.9 million population25 of the Highlands region will benefit from the 
Investment Program, the immediate beneficiaries of Project 1 will be the 400,000 people living 
near  the  roads  included  in  Project  1.  Anticipated  economic  benefits  as  a  result  of  road 
improvement and maintenance include (i) increased diversity of cash crops, higher production, 
and  more  direct  sales  as  a  result  of  better  access  to  regional  markets  and  towns;  (ii) 
rehabilitation of abandoned coffee gardens and/or establishment of new gardens; (iii) more 
raising of livestock for sale; (iv) more sales by  market vendors because of the increase in 
customers;  (v)  better  business  for  trade  store  owners;  and  (vi)  more  opportunities  for  the 
creation and/or expansion of microenterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises. The 
greater availability, frequency, and reliability and the lower costs of transport services will benefit 
the public motor vehicle (PMV) drivers and truckers as well as people who rely on them. 
Anticipated  social  benefits  include:  (i)  greater  accessibility  to  schools,  leading  to  higher 
enrollments, fewer drop-outs, and better academic performance; (ii) better access to health 
care, leading to improved health outcomes; (iii) better access to government services, including 
new services such as electricity; (iv) more opportunities to diversify and expand agricultural

B.  Economic Analysis 
70.  An economic analysis has been prepared for the 211 km roads under Project 1 that will 
be improved under the direction of the DOW and then transferred to the NRA for maintenance. 
In addition, 370 km of roads that are in good condition will be maintained by the NRA. The 
analysis follows the standard practice of comparing life-cycle road agency and user costs with 
and without the project, based on analysis with the highway development and management 
model (HDM-4). The analysis focuses on savings in transport costs. Value added from better 
transport  links  resulting  in  increased  opportunities  for  agriculture  and  employment  are  not 
quantified in this analysis but are captured through benefits to generated traffic.  
 
71.  Traffic volume on Project 1 roads exceeded 400 vehicles per day at the beginning of the 
decade, but has fallen to as low as 160 vehicles in some sections as a result of the poor state of 
the road network, the associated suppression of economic activity, and an increase in tribal 
tensions. Population growth and the improvement in economic condition of the Project 1 area 
suggest there is realistic potential for a return to previous volumes. The economic analysis 
assumes the road improvements will trigger a one-off increase in traffic to midway between 
current and historic volumes, followed by a 6% annual growth in traffic. The Project passes the 
12% threshold even without the increase in traffic.

C.   Financial Management and Sustainability 
 
73.  A financial management assessment was undertaken in June 2008, in accordance with 
ADB  requirements.26  Among  other  things,  the  assessment  considered  the  financial 
management arrangements for the Road Maintenance and Upgrading (Sector) Project (footnote 
3). The assessment rated the overall inherent risk as substantial and the overall control risk as 
high.27 Particular weaknesses concerned record keeping, internal controls, project accounting 
and  reporting,  and  understanding  of  and  adherence  to  financial  management  policies  and 
procedures. In response, the financial management arrangements for the proposed Investment 
Program will be significantly stronger than those for previous projects. Specific measures will 
include  capacity  building  support  and  the  provision  of  independent  accounting  support  to 
ensure, among other things, timely and rigorous reconciliations, orderly record keeping, and 
strict adherence to financial management policies and internal controls. Project 1 is not a 
revenue-earning project and, as such, does not require financial analysis. 
 
74.  Analysis was undertaken to assess the Government’s counterpart funding for Project 1 
and its capacity to service the debt. The Government is committed to timely provision of the 
required counterpart funding during implementation of Project 1 and is favorably positioned to 
service the debt from the Project. The ratio of external debt to GDP of 18% in 2007 (expected to 
fall to 11.4% by 2010) is substantially below the 30% threshold maximum level of external debt 
set by the International Monetary Fund and World Bank for low-income countries such as PNG. 
In  September  2007,  Standard  &  Poor’s  upgraded  the  foreign  currency  rating  of  the  debt 
securities of the PNG Government to ‘B+’ and its local currency rating to ‘BB–’. Although 
external debt is below threshold levels, PNG has been assessed by the International Monetary 
Fund as at moderate risk of debt stress given its exposure to world oil and mineral prices and 
the  ongoing  risk  of  overspending  by  the  public  sector.  The  MFF  is  expected  to  have  a 
manageable impact on the country’s debt situation. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social Impacts 
 
75.  Poverty levels are increasing. Most people have land and are able to grow sufficient food 
to meet basic household consumption needs but there are wide discrepancies in the well-being 
of different segments of society, particularly as livelihoods are increasingly linked to the cash 
economy. According to the 1996 household survey, 37% of the population were living below a 
poverty line of $350 (K461) per year. Furthermore, 17% of the population was unable to meet 
the basic food requirement of 2,200 calories per day per adult equivalent. Poor economic 
performance and rapid population growth have led to a sharp increase in the incidence of 
poverty to 53.8% in 2003.  In the same period, poverty levels elsewhere in the Pacific region 
dropped from 15% in 1996 to 10% in 2003. Poverty in PNG is concentrated in rural areas, 
where the poverty level (41%) is significantly higher than in urban areas (16%). A poverty 
mapping exercise indicates that 5 of the 20 disadvantaged districts in PNG are in Southern 
Highlands and Enga provinces.

76.  The  Investment  Program  incorporates  several  strategies  to  facilitate  the  ability  of 
communities and households to realize benefits from road improvements and maintenance and, 
thereby,  reduce  poverty  in  the  Highlands  region.  The  design  includes  (i)  priorities  for 
employment of local men and women in road rehabilitation and maintenance; (ii) civil work 
contracts to include the provision of HIV awareness and prevention programs in construction 
camps  and  neighboring  communities;  and  (iii)  an  extensive  community  relations  and  a 
participation program linked to different aspects of subproject preparation and implementation. 
 
77.  During Investment Program preparation, potential gender benefits and impacts on local 
communities  and  vulnerable  groups  were  analyzed  through  a  stakeholder  consultation 
workshop, key informant interviews, focus group discussions, and small-sample surveys. The 
women who were consulted on the Project 1 roads strongly endorsed the road improvements. 
They expected to be able to increase their agricultural production and to expand into new crops 
and animal rearing. As a result, they anticipated increasing their market sales. They felt that 
they  would  have  faster  (and  perhaps  cheaper)  access  to  health  care  facilities.  Road 
improvements will enable their children to go to schools and, in general, their communities will 
have  better  access  to  government  services.  The  gender  division  of  labor  and  women’s 
traditional exclusion from the benefits derived from road rehabilitation and maintenance works 
were  clearly  identified  during  focus  group  discussions  with  public  works  constructors.  The 
Investment  Program  will  seek  to  give  women  more  access  to  jobs  provided  by  the  road 
improvement by encouraging civil works contractors to increase the percentage of women 
workers to 30% of the labor force, and to carry out gender-sensitive HIV prevention and road 
safety awareness in the project area. 
 
78.  Papua New Guinea is characterized by a generalized HIV epidemic, with prevalence 
rates of 1.65% among the 15–49 year age group in rural areas. This is projected to increase to 
5.5% by 2011 if no major initiatives are taken to control spread of the infection. Key at-risk 
groups include truck drivers, including those that work on the Highlands Highway; female sex 
workers, particularly at PMV stops along the Highway; and men who migrate to towns and 
development enclaves for work. Wives and their new-born children are also at risk because the 
use  of  condoms  is  not  widespread  and  there  is  a  high  degree  of  sexual  violence  within 
marriages. The exposure of currently isolated communities to new levels of road traffic means 
that special attention must be paid to the risk of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). In light of 
women’s greater exposure to the risks and impacts of HIV, culturally sensitive and gender-
responsive awareness and behavior change initiatives need to be provided in campsites and 
corridors of influence as part of broader health education programs. The Investment Program 
will coordinate with existing HIV prevention projects financed by ADB and other development 
partners such as AusAID, New Zealand Agency for International Development, UNAIDS—the 
joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS—and World Health Organization. A summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12.

F.  Social Safeguards 
  1.  Involuntary Resettlement 
 
82.  The  Government  has  already  acquired  the  public  road  reserve  for  the  Highlands 
Highway from Lae to Mendi and plans to acquire land along all Project 1 roads. Existing roads in 
the Highlands region are generally on customary land, the use of which has been agreed in 
consultation with the clans and communities that jointly own the land. The additional land 
needed for road improvement works for Project 1 is very minor; the amount will be determined 
by the detail engineering design of the roads. As formal land acquisition is a long and time-
consuming process, the Government will negotiate a memorandum of agreement (MOA) with 
the affected clans and communities to allow the use of land for road improvements. In parallel, 
the Government will begin acquisition procedures for public road reserves along the Investment 
Program roads through a process of State alienation of customary land as per the Land Act, 
1996. Affected clans and communities will be compensated for land; individuals and households 
with assets on the land will be compensated for any damage to or loss of these assets; and, 
through agreements with clans and communities, they will continue to occupy and use land in 
the road reserves outside that required to improve the roads. 
 
83.  A resettlement framework (summarized in Appendix 14) has been reviewed by the PNG 
Government to establish the policies and procedures for payment of compensation for lost or 
damaged assets. The land acquisition impacts, where they occur, will be minor. There will be no 
displacement of housing and the affected people will experience only small losses of crops,

23 
trees, fences or other secondary structures. The Project is categorized as B with respect to 
involuntary resettlement. Short resettlement plans have been prepared for Project 1 roads and 
these will be updated based on detailed engineering designs during loan implementation.  
 
  2.  Indigenous People 
 
84.  Papua New Guinea has over 800 different language groups. In the Highlands region, 
patriarchal societies are organized on the basis of clans belonging to different tribes; in Enga 
and the Southern Highlands provinces, the Huli, Enga, Ipili, and Angal are the principal linguistic 
and tribal groups in the areas of Project 1. Each clan has a specified territory that is owned 
jointly by and supports the needs of its members; individuals and households are allocated land 
within the clan territory according to their needs to build a home and establish a food and cash 
crop garden. All tribes rely on subsistence agriculture based on the cultivation of sweet potato; 
cash income is generated primarily through the sale of cash crops such as coffee, potato, and 
pyrethrum. In general, no tribes or ethnic groups consider themselves to be minorities. The 
resettlement framework and plans will address specific actions favorable to indigenous peoples, 
if necessary, in dealing with the customary land acquisition. The Project is classified as B with 
respect to the ADB indigenous people’s policy. 
 
G.  Assumptions and Risks 
85.  The Investment Program includes the following assumptions and risks.  
 
(i)  NRA’s effectiveness. Although the NRA board started functioning in 2004, the 
NRA has remained inadequately staffed. A chief executive officer was appointed 
in 2007. The 3-year duration of the board expired in 2007 and a new board was 
approved on 14 May 2008. The NRA is now actively recruiting key staff. Initial 
assistance for operational and financial management system will be provided 
through  ongoing  TA,  and  complemented  by  extensive  capacity  development 
under the Investment Program. Capacity development of the NRA and improving 
its effectiveness is critical to the success of the Investment Program.  
 
(ii)  Road maintenance funding. The NRA manages a road fund financed through a 
fuel levy based on very low rates. The NRA is also authorized and plans to 
collect road damage charges on heavy vehicles. Supplemented by Government 
financing, these resources are barely adequate to maintain the HCRN. Additional 
resources are needed to expand NRA’s maintenance responsibility to maintain 
the entire national road network. The Investment Program includes assistance to 
the  NRA  to  prepare  fresh  proposals  for  the  Government  to  increase  road 
maintenance funding. Political support for such proposals will be crucial.  
 
(iii)  Shortage of civil work contractors. Implementation of ongoing road-related 
works has been adversely affected by a lack of capable international and national 
contractors. The problem is compounded in the Highlands region by security 
conditions. The Government is aware of the issues and is taking measures to  
(i) provide safety to international contractors through the provincial governments, 
and (ii) improve licensing and classification of national contractors, and provide 
opportunities  to  SME construction  industry.  It  is  expected  that  the  long-term 
maintenance  contracts  will  attract  international  contractors  and  facilitate  joint 
ventures with national firms.

24 
(iv)  Land acquisition and resettlement. Because of customary landholding in PNG, 
land acquisition is intricate and the process is long. The DOW normally seeks 
approval of communities to carry out improvement work on roads through a 
memorandum of agreement but without formal acquisition. This has led to regular 
interruptions  of  work  on  the  ongoing  road  projects  in  the  Highlands  region. 
However, the DOW has now started to acquire rights of way for major roads in 
the Highlands region. The Investment Program will help the DOW to carry out 
field surveys and prepare land acquisition documents for all Investment Program 
roads to enable it to make payments and acquire rights of way.  
 
(v)  Security. Security in the Highlands region remains an issue with the contractors 
working on ongoing road projects. It is important that the DOW, with the support 
of the provincial governments, addresses this issue.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  The Transport System 
 
1.  The island nature of Papua New Guinea, together with the absence of land connections 
between several of the mainland provinces, ensures that domestic aviation and coastal shipping 
play an important role. The main commercial port is Lae, which is the gateway for Morobe 
Province and the Highlands region, with Port Moresby as the second main port. The large 
Sepik, Fly, and Ramu river systems provide access to the interior, and there are many small 
ports  of  call  around  the  coast  and  islands  which  provide  the  means  of  access  for  some 
communities.  
2.  Domestic  air  services—operated  by  Air  Niugini—link  Port  Moresby  and  Lae  to  the 
provincial capitals. Charter and private general aviation services link smaller centers and remote 
inland villages where there are no external connections by road. Air links provided by missions 
to support health centers and schools formed an important part of the early development of 
transport within Papua New Guinea, and still retain a significant role today. 
3.  Road transport is by far the dominant passenger travel mode. The Highlands Highway, 
and roads leading from it, form the largest contiguous network, linking the Highlands provinces 
with the main port at Lae. The Highlands Highway branches west of Mount Hagen into the 
Southern Highlands Highway and Enga Highway. It links to Madang via the Ramu Highway and 
to Popondetta (Morobe province). There are other separate smaller road networks on mainland 
PNG in Port Moresby (NCD, Central and Gulf Provinces), Alotau (Milne Bay), Wewak (East 
Sepik), Vanimo (Sandaun) and in Western Province, and there are networks in the island 
provinces radiating out from the provincial capitals. 
B.  The Road Network and Condition 
4.  The road network is classified into national, provincial, and district roads. There are 
7,600 km of national roads under central Government administration and funding, of which 
2,600  km  are  sealed  and  the  remainder  are  gravel.  Provincial  and  district  roads  are  the 
administrative and funding responsibility of provincial governments. Their number and total 
length has been changing as provinces create new districts and designate existing tracks as 
provincial roads. The total length is about 10,000 km, of which only about 1,000 km are sealed. 
The remainder are gravel or earth. 
5.  National roads provide a strategic rural network, linking provinces, provincial capitals, 
and other main population centers. National roads are categorized as (i) national routes linking 
population centers in two or more provinces or main roads traversing the entire length of an 
island province acting as a collector road; (ii) national main roads linking major population 
centers  and  districts  to  national  routes,  or  to  strategically  important  centers  (main  towns, 
harbors, and airports); (iii) national district roads within a single district linking small towns and 
villages to centers within the district; and (iv) national institutional roads linking Government 
institutions  (universities,  defense  establishments,  hospitals)  to  the  national  road  network. 
Provincial roads are categorized into provincial trunk, district feeder, local access and other 
unclassified roads, including private roads and some local town roads. 
6.  Only about 40% of the national road network is considered to be in a maintainable 
condition, i.e., the road has not deteriorated to a point beyond which funds can be applied cost- 
effectively to maintain the road to an acceptable standard of service. For the remaining 60% of 
roads, maintenance is confined to minimum emergency repairs to keep the road passable, but

32   Appendix 2 
these roads will deteriorate progressively until new funds become available for reconstruction or 
rehabilitation. About half the network requires some significant rehabilitation, restoration, or 
reconstruction to make the roads trafficable.   
 
7.  About 30% of the surveyed network is in the Highlands region. Based on data from the 
Department of Works (DOW) road asset management system (RAMS), the condition of national 
roads is 13% good, 42% fair and 44% poor. The Highlands roads are in a poorer condition than 
national roads in general, with none classed as good and over two thirds classed as poor. 
 
C.  Traffic Volume and Vehicle Fleet  
 
8.  Traffic volumes on the national highway network, outside the urban centers of Port 
Moresby and Lae, are low. About 74% of the national network (by length) carries fewer than 500 
vehicles a day and 89% fewer than 1,000 vehicles a day. There is even less traffic on provincial 
and lower-level networks. On the Highlands Highway, which is the main traffic artery for the 
region, traffic volumes vary between 500 and 2,000 vehicles a day on rural sections, with lower 
volumes across the mountain passes and higher volumes in the more heavily populated valley 
sections. 
 
9.  Road vehicle registration is carried out at provincial traffic registries and data reporting 
back to the National Land Transport Board is uneven. The most reliable information on the size 
and growth of the vehicle fleet comes from the number of compulsory third party insurance 
policies taken out and recorded by the Motor Vehicles Insurance Trust (MVIT). The latest 
information dates from 2002 and indicates a registered vehicle fleet of 49,000. However, the 
accuracy of this figure is unknown and the total is considerably lower than an earlier figure from 
the same source in 1999 of 60,900 vehicles. 
 
D.  Road Sector Institutions, Administration, and Funding 
 
10.  The  Department  of  Transport  (DOT)  is  responsible  for  national  transport  policy 
formulation, planning, safety and the regulation of transport operations. The NLTB implements 
these policies in respect of driver licensing, vehicle safety and inspection, licensing of heavy 
vehicles on interprovincial routes, for-hire transport and motor-vehicle dealerships. The DOT’s 
Land Transport Division (LTD) acts as the Board’s secretariat. Provincial land transport boards 
regulate commercial passenger and goods transport within the provinces, although in practice 
there is little effective control. Provincial governments are responsible for all vehicle registration 
and LTD attempts to consolidate reports at a national level but in practice the statistics are late, 
incomplete and unreliable, so the number of vehicles operating on the network is not precisely 
known. 
 
11.  The DOW is responsible for management of road maintenance and capital works on the 
national  road  network  and  provides  some  technical  advice  and  support  to  provincial 
governments. The National Roads Authority (NRA) has assumed maintenance responsibility for 
the first section of the Highlands Highway between Lae and Nadzab, and it is intended that it will 
progressively take on responsibility for the management of road maintenance delivery for all 
national  roads,  starting  with  the  Highlands  region.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  National 
Planning (MFNP) is responsible for physical and economic planning at national level and for 
approval of the budget requests from the line agencies. It administers some minor parts of the 
road program directly, in particular the District Road Improvement Program. Interagency and 
private sector communications and consultation on land transport matters are facilitated by the 
Transport Sector Coordination, Monitoring and Implementation Committee.

12.  Provincial governments are responsible for the maintenance and development of all 
provincial roads. Their technical and administrative capacity to carry out this task varies and 
some provinces rely on the provincial arms of the DOW for assistance, through formal or 
informal agreements. In a few cases, where the DOW has been unable to fund adequate 
upkeep of national roads of importance to particular provinces, the provinces have provided 
maintenance support. 
 
13.  The National Road Safety Council (NRSC) is a semi-independent body that coordinates 
and promotes road safety. It was set up in 1999 and is chaired by DOT, but its membership 
includes representatives of concerned government and private agencies. It is funded from a 5% 
levy on compulsory motor vehicle third-party insurance premiums.  
 
E.  Road Funding and Investment 
 
14.  The present system of national road funding is in several parts: (i) the majority of funding 
is through annual budget submissions by the DOW to MFNP, appropriation of the agreed 
allocation through the national budget, and disbursement to the DOW against warrants for 
specific items of expenditure; (ii) the NRA receives a direct operating allocation from the budget 
and can draw monies from the newly created road fund against its road maintenance program; 
(iii) provincial governments receive a budget allocation from central government and they are 
free  to  allocate  this  against  provincial  programs,  including  provincial  roads;  (iv)  individual 
government ministers receive allocations for expenditure within their electoral districts, part of 
which may go to provincial roads; and (v) some private companies receive tax credits in return 
for funding maintenance of certain road sections, mainly on roads essential for access to the oil 
and gas fields and metal mining. 
 
15.  Investment in the road sector has averaged K500 million per year over the last 3 years. 
Of this, 15% has been spent on road upgrading, 56% on rehabilitation and replacement, 21% on 
maintenance (routine, periodic, and emergency), and 6% on operations (road safety, policing) 
and  administration.  Forward  expenditure  for  2008  is  at  a  similar  level,  but  direct  central 
government expenditure on the road sector is projected to reduce to K150 million a year by 
2012 as current donor-assisted programs end.  
 
F.  Government’s Strategy 
 
16.  The Government’s strategy for the transport sector is designed to achieve the objectives 
of the Medium-Term Development Strategy (MTDS) and is set out in the National Transport 
Development Plan (NTDP) Update, 2006–2010. The NTDP is in two parts, the first addresses 
sector  policy  and  institutional  development  and  the  second  the  infrastructure  investment 
program. The NTDP’s overall aim is “to provide safe and dependable transport services to all 
sections of the community in PNG in a cost-efficient and effective manner.” The NTDP vision 
includes: (i) better transport access to education, health and other rural welfare and government 
services, and increased personal mobility, for all persons in the community at all times; (ii) better 
transport  access  to  production  sites  and  markets,  at  lower  transport  cost;  (iii)  enhanced 
opportunities for raising income levels in remote and impoverished coastal rural areas; and  
(iv) lower transport costs and safer cargo and passenger movements. 
 
17.  To achieve this aim in the road sector, the strategy will (i) maintain and improve the 
existing infrastructure and services; (ii) upgrade, rehabilitate and carry out new construction 
works only where economically feasible; and (iii) conduct business on "safety and security first" 
basis. NTDP proposes to raise funds directly from road users and to deposit revenues into a

road fund to be managed by the NRA. The NRA will assume all road maintenance functions 
currently undertaken by the DOW. Initially, the authority will concentrate on maintenance of 
roads in the Highlands region and this will be followed by other national highways, depending on 
their priority. 
 
18.  Other policy initiatives include (i) new approaches to funding and finance, in particular 
the introduction of road user cost recovery to generate revenues for maintenance; (ii) promoting 
stronger  partnerships  with  private  sector  companies;  (iii)  seeking  closer  working  relations 
between national and provincial governments; and (iv) adopting more integrated and strategic 
approaches to transport planning, policy formulation, and decision-making processes. 
 
19.  The road investment plan identified 16 priority sections of the national highway for 
rehabilitation over the plan period. Once all the national highways are brought to acceptable 
levels, it is anticipated that the NRA will focus attention on provincial roads. The NRA is 
intended to be self-sustaining, capable of generating income through various revenue measures 
to fund its operations and to carry out its designated functions and responsibilities. The priority 
roads include about 900 km in the Highlands region: the Highlands Highway, including the 
Southern Highlands and Enga Highways; Baiyer River Road; Koroba-Mendi Road; and the 
Porgera-Togoba  Road.  The  Government  also  has  a  district  road  improvement  program 
administered by the Department of National Planning intended to fulfill a community service 
obligation for roads that do not justify development on strict economic criteria. 
 
G.  Road Transport Regulation 
 
20.  Public passenger transport is provided by passenger motor vehicles (PMVs), mainly 
vans and small buses of 12 to 30 seats, operated on a route licensing system. In 2004, from 
insurance records, there were about 5,300 registered PMVs in the country, of which some 1,300 
were in NCD, 1,000 in Lae, and 2,000 in the Highlands. There were about 1,100 taxis, almost all 
in Port Moresby.  
 
21.  The largest urban PMV network is in Port Moresby, which has a planned route structure, 
although  this  has  not  been  reviewed  for  some  years.  Regulatory  enforcement  is  weak, 
deviations from routes and service schedules are common, and some of the 24 routes are no 
longer operating.  
 
22.  Passenger fares are regulated and fares are increased on receipt of submissions from 
the operators and after taking account of cost increases indicated by a PMV and taxi cost model 
operated by the NLTB. Regulation of fares is undertaken by the Independent Consumer and 
Competition Commission (ICCC), which recently undertook a comprehensive review of PMV 
and taxi costs and fare structures and set a new fare determination and review process for the 
next 5 years.1  
 
23.  Market entry and inter-provincial routes served are regulated for “hire-or-reward” goods 
transport, with a focus on the Highlands Highway. Tariffs are lodged annually with the DOT or 
its appointed agent and a minimum 60-day notice of intended increases is required, with public 
rights  of  objection  and  official  determination.  Government  policy  is  to  replace  the  existing 
quantity-licensing system with a quality-based licensing system.  This would require operators to 
show  that  they  have  appropriate  managerial  expertise,  business  experience,  and  financial 
backing before they are granted an operating license.

24.  Overloading of goods vehicles is one of the factors blamed for the rapid deterioration of 
Highlands  roads,  and  for  the  network  in  general.  An  axle  load  survey  found  that  15%  of

H.  Road Safety 
 
26.  While there is a complete absence of up-to-date statistical data, the road crash and 
injury rates for Papua New Guinea are estimated to be one of the highest in the Pacific region, if 
not the highest. Data from 2002 indicate a road fatality rate of 40 per 10,000 registered vehicles, 
four  times  higher  than  for  the  Fiji  Islands  and  40  times  higher  than  the  best  performing 
countries.  The  main  causes  of  traffic  accidents  are  drunk  driving,  inadequate  road  safety 
awareness by drivers and pedestrians, an absence of uniform traffic engineering standards, 
hazardous roads, and inadequate enforcement of traffic rules. 
 
27.  ADB provided technical assistance (TA)2 from 1984 to 1996. The TA established a road 
accident reporting and analysis system within the LTD, was instrumental in setting up NRSC, 
and undertook accident black spot and remedial treatment analysis and staff training. While the 
NRSC continues to operate and has recently been revitalized under new management, the 
computer system for accident data analysis was lost in a fire that destroyed DOT’s headquarters 
office in the late 1990s. Since then, the NRSC has effectively taken over the lead role in road 
safety from the LTD. It funds small projects to educate the community in road safety, raise 
standards of traffic enforcement and bring stakeholders together to tackle the issues. It plans to 
expand into vehicle safety enforcement and to reestablish a basic traffic accident database from 
several years of accumulated police accident records. Road safety has yet to be fully instituted 
across the road sector agencies; in particular, the DOW has not introduced an effective safety 
audit function into its design procedures, and no agency is carrying out hazard identification and 
safety management across the road network.

ROAD MAINTENANCE AND THE NATIONAL ROADS AUTHORITY 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  With support from its development partners, the Government determined in November 
2002 to establish a National Roads Authority (NRA) as a noncommercial statutory authority to 
assume responsibility for financing, managing and delivering road maintenance services.  
 
B.  Functions and Responsibilities 
2.  The  Government’s  decision  to  establish  the  NRA1 led  quickly  to  the  drafting  and 
enactment by Parliament of a National Roads Authority Act in May 2003, which was gazetted in 
April 2004.2 
 
3.  The  objectives  of  the  NRA  as  recorded  in  the  act3 are  (i)  to  raise  funds  for  the 
maintenance of public roads; (ii) to ensure the efficient preparation of effective and annual road 
maintenance  programmes;  and  (iii)  to  ensure  that  all  routine,  periodic  and  emergency 
maintenance of roads is executed by the NRA in a transparent, effective, and efficient manner. 
The  purpose  is  to  optimize  the  contribution  of  road  assets  to  the  economic  and  social 
development of PNG. 
 
4.  Implementation of this statement of objectives requires the NRA to be responsible for  
(i) collecting funds for road maintenance, (ii) planning and programming priority needs for road 
maintenance,  (iii)  procuring  and  administering  contracts  for  road  maintenance  works,  
(iv)  monitoring  and  inspecting  the  executed  works  to  ensure  their  compliance  with  quality 
standards, and (v) detailed reporting of activities and outcomes to Parliament.  
 
C.  Background to Establishment of the NRA 
5.  The  Government’s  decision  to  create  a  new  and  specialist  road  maintenance 
organization  was  supported  within  government  and  among  user  groups.  The  idea  of 
establishing a road authority and/or road fund has been considered by a number of studies.4  
 
6.  The  need  for  change  was  also  reflected  in  the  Government’s  National  Transport 
Development Plan, 2001–2010 and its revision covering 2006–2010, both of which called for the 
restructuring of road maintenance organizations and for the introduction of a cost-recovery 
system based on road user charges.

road user charges, and to support the transparent monitoring of delivered maintenance works 
against agreed performance indicators. Using RAMS, the cost-recovery revenues coming into 
the NRA’s road fund will be allocated to critical road sections, i.e., those where maintenance 
can have the greatest impact by reducing vehicle operating costs.  
 
12.  To complement its maintenance planning, the NRA will also be responsible for managing 
the  delivery  of  road  maintenance  services  outsourced  to  private  contractors.  To  control

performance-based contracts. These will require the selected contractors to take responsibility 
for maintaining road sections to specified standards and for a specified number of years. 
 
3.  Maintenance Financing 
13.  It is intended that funds for NRA road maintenance programs will ultimately come wholly 
from road user charges. The National Roads Authority Act permits the NRA to establish and 
operate a road fund to be funded primarily from road user charges. The road fund will be used 
primarily  to  pay  for  the  contracting  of  road  maintenance  services  and,  ultimately,  the 
administration expenses of the NRA. The road user charges will comprise:   
 
(i)   a road use charge, which will be a levy or surcharge on gasoline and diesel 
intended to cover the costs associated with the general use of roads; and  
(ii)  a road damage charge, which will be a heavy vehicle charge, based on the laden 
axle weight of vehicles, intended to cover costs attributable to different vehicles, 
depending on their size and weight.  
 
14.  The principal reasons for establishing such a road fund are: (i) to secure a more reliable 
and sustainable level of funding for road maintenance than has been available from government 
budgetary allocations, which have been subject to funding shortfalls and annual variations; (ii) to 
protect funds raised from road user charges against raids on those funds for use on other 
purposes; (iii) to establish a close fee-for-service link between the charges paid by users and 
the road maintenance service received by users; (iv) to provide a lever to secure more efficient, 
cost-effective  and  customer-responsive  road  sector  management;  and  (v)  to  allow  users 
themselves to have a greater say in how road maintenance funds are managed. A properly 
established and operating road fund is considered a prerequisite to the successful operation of 
the NRA.  
 
15.  When fully operational, the amounts levied by the road use charge and the road damage 
charge will vary. They will be influenced by such factors as the volume of road maintenance 
works to be undertaken in the coming year, changes in road maintenance unit costs, fuel 
consumption levels (which can be expected to increase as vehicle usage increases, along with 
a growing domestic economy), the volatility of international oil prices, the national economy, and 
similar considerations. 
 
16.  As at September 2008, this cost recovery system had been only partially implemented. 
An NEC decision in July 2005 permitted the NRA to collect revenue from: (i) a road use charge 
on fuel, represented by an increase of 4 toea5 a litre on diesel; (ii) a road damage charge on 
vehicles with a gross vehicle weight exceeding 4 tons; and (iii) tax credits granted by the 
government to resource companies. The road use charge currently generates about K16 million 
a year for the NRA’s road fund. The accumulated amount in the fund from this source is 
expected to reach almost K50 million by the end of 2008. Application of the road damage 
charge currently is being worked out, and discussions on using funds from tax credits are just 
beginning. 
 
17.  To support the NRA in its establishment phase, the Government has been providing it 
with two types of financing: (i) since 2005, it has funded its administration costs from annual 
recurrent budgets, and this is expected to continue until the road use charge can cover these

18.  To facilitate the effective management of the NRA and its use of funds, suitable financial 
management, management information, and internal audit systems are being put in place. 
These  will  cover  budgeting  for  maintenance  and  administrative  expenditures,  receipt  of

NRA bank account, expenditure planning, cash flow forecasting, financial accounting, and the 
recording of actual expenditure on contracts. These will enable NRA managers to monitor 
details by contract, type of contract, road sections, and type of maintenance work, among 
others. Standard accounting and auditing procedures, appropriate for a statutory authority, and 
consistent with the NRA’s obligations under the Public Finances (Management) Act, 1995 will 
be developed.  
 
19.  The NRA has a reporting responsibility to parliament through its Minister for Transport. 
The content and form of NRA reports are intended to provide (i) sufficient information to account

performance in meeting its objectives; and (ii) promotion of the activities and standing of the 
authority, and information to road users and the general public about the authority’s aims, 
operations,  and  effectiveness.  Additionally,  once  the  authority  begins  its  maintenance

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) has adopted the Medium-Term Development Strategy (MTDS), 
2005–2010 as its strategic framework to promote national development. The overarching goal of the MTDS is 
export-driven economic growth, rural development and poverty reduction, including through good governance 
and the promotion of sustainable agriculture, forestry, fisheries, and tourism. The strategy will be realized by 
empowering Papua New Guineans, especially those in rural areas, to mobilize their own resources for higher 
living standards. The key priorities for the period to 2010 are (i) rehabilitation and maintenance of transport 
infrastructure, (ii) promotion of income-earning opportunities, (iii) basic education and adult education, (iv) 
primary health care and HIV prevention, and (v) law and justice. In the transport sector, rehabilitation of the 
Highlands Highway is one of the Government’s top priorities. 
The purpose of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country strategy and program in PNG, 2006−2010, is to 
help the Government meet its MTDS goals. ADB and the Government have agreed that the strategic areas that 
clearly satisfy the principles and lessons are: (i) public financial management, (ii) private sector development, (iii) 
the transport sector, and (iv) health and HIV. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
In rural PNG, most people have land: in the Highlands region, an extended family or sub-clan may have up to 3–
5 hectares of productive land divided into 10 or more small gardens that are used to cultivate a range of food and 
cash crops. Households are generally able to grow food to meet basic household consumption needs; of the 
households surveyed for the Highlands Region Road Improvement Investment Program, more than 70% had 
sufficient food in their gardens for 3 months or more. A small household coffee garden may generate K500 from 
annual sales. Rural people also have extensive family and clan networks to assist them in times of need. 
Nonetheless, and particularly as people’s livelihoods are increasingly linked to a cash economy, there are wide 
discrepancies in the well-being of different segments of society. In addition to low incomes, a 2001 participatory 
poverty assessment (funded by ADB) clearly indicated the non-income dimensions of poverty: specifically, people 
considered they were poor when they lacked (i) jobs, (ii) land, (iii) education, (iv) services such as health and 
water, and (v) transport and roads. The most pressing needs were safe drinking water and usable roads. While 
available data are limited and need to be updated, the risks of rapidly rising poverty levels in PNG are clear. 
Salient issues include the following.  
(i)  In 1997, 37% of the population lived below a poverty line of $350 (K461) per year. A further 17% of 
population was unable to meet the basic adult food requirement of 2,200 calories per day. In terms of the 
international poverty line, one-quarter of people in PNG lived on less than $1/day; 54% lived on less than 
$2/day. 
(ii)  Poor economic performance and rapid population growth have led to a sharp increase in the incidence of 
poverty, from 37.5% in 1996 to 53.8% in 2003. It is estimated that 40% of the PNG population lived on less 
than $1/day in 2003, while 70% were below the level of $2/day. 
(iii) Poverty is concentrated in rural areas. The rural poverty rate (41%) is significantly higher than the urban rate 
(16%). The Highlands region, which contains 40% of the national population and has a poverty rate (1996) of 
38.3%, is one of the poorest regions in the country. 
(iv) Five of the 20 most disadvantaged districts are located in Enga and Southern Highlands provinces, the 
provinces targeted by the first tranche of the Investment Program. 
(v)  The highest poverty levels occur among households with little or no cash income, i.e., families that rely 
primarily on subsistence agriculture, hunting, gathering and fishing to meet household consumption needs.
